notes: Fifth-generation LS flagship sedan. Available as LS 500 (twin-turbo V6) or LS 500h (hybrid). AWD available. Advanced luxury features. Hybrid system requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus LS article, January 2025 revision.

Seventh-generation ES mid-size luxury sedan. Available as ES 350 (V6) or ES 300h (hybrid). AWD available on V6 models. Front-wheel drive based. Hybrid requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus ES article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation IS sport sedan refresh. Available with turbo I4 or V6. RWD or AWD. F Sport variants. Compact sport sedan competing with BMW 3-Series. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus IS article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation NX compact luxury crossover. Available as NX 250 (turbo), NX 350h (hybrid), or NX 450h+ (PHEV). PHEV offers 37 miles electric range. Hybrid and PHEV systems require specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus NX article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation RX luxury crossover. Available as RX 350 (V6) or RX 450h (hybrid). Best-selling Lexus model. Three-row RX 350L variant. Hybrid requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus RX article, January 2025 revision.

High-performance RX variant. Turbo hybrid produces 366 hp. 0-60 mph in 5.9 seconds. Torque vectoring AWD. Most powerful RX ever. Performance hybrid complexity requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus RX article, January 2025 revision.

New three-row luxury crossover. Larger than RX. Available as TX 350 (turbo) or TX 500h (hybrid). Seating for up to 7. Hybrid system requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus TX article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation GX body-on-frame luxury SUV. Based on Toyota Land Cruiser Prado. V8-only powertrain. Off-road capability. Three-row seating. Long production run. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus GX article, January 2025 revision.

All-new third-generation GX. Twin-turbo V6 replaces V8. Enhanced off-road capability. Body-on-frame construction. Three-row seating. Turbocharged complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus GX article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation LX flagship SUV. Based on Toyota Land Cruiser J300. Twin-turbo V6 replaces V8. Advanced off-road systems. Three-row seating for 7. Turbocharged complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus LX article, January 2025 revision.

Grand touring luxury coupe. Available as LC 500 (V8) or LC 500h (hybrid). Convertible variant available. 0-60 mph in 4.4 seconds (V8). Stunning design. Hybrid requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus LC article, January 2025 revision.

First dedicated Lexus battery electric vehicle. 71.4 kWh battery pack. Up to 220-mile range. Dual-motor AWD. Based on e-TNGA platform. High-voltage EV system requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus RZ article, January 2025 revision.
